content.description:
In the middle of the Camel Area is a left facing series of features (flakes and small corner up a very solid line of rock. Climb around the small overhanging features. Ascend to a ledge. Climbing the slightly overhanging line to the wrap station (three bolts).

There are no rings at the top of this route and the bolts are glue-ins. Expect to rap off.

Trad. Bring the kitchen sink.

To the left of the prominent arch that constitutes Harlequin is a series of large and blocky right facing features. It looks downright ugly, but looks deceive. Climb through these left facing features, tending left. As you approach the cliff top, traverse right to the Fixe anchors. This is a good introductory trad route that offers good practice in rope management over relatively well protected terrain. Make sure you have a follower to clean, retrieving your last piece before the traverse to anchors is very difficult on rappel

Trad

A retro-bolted old-school trad route. The crux is right at the beginning, protected by two well placed bolts. Angle slight left to obvious flake. Follow to anchors.

About 10m right of Camel, where a thin, steep crack is protected with two bolts.
Retro-bolted (with permission). 6 bolts. Bolted anchors.

In the Camel area there is a prominent buttress of which has two prominent roofs. The start of the route ascends the slab just left of the lower roof. Climb up and right towards the lower roof. Stay left of lower roof and aim for the left facing corner that leads up to the higher roof. Climb left around the higher roof. Traverse left under the cedar. Climb up onto the ledge where the wrap station resides. This is a technical, sustained 5.7.

Trad

Starts at the broken up section of wall 6m right of Camel. Climb this to the crack above which leads to the same ledge as Camel. To finish continue up and left (5.3) and build an anchor from the exposed rock, or take the Camel crack (5.7) to the Camel 
 anchors.

N43.42568 W79.8855
Standard Trad Rack

Originally climbed on gear, it was bolted in 2012.

Bolts

This route resides on the north end of the Camel Wall. It is just left of J-Bean, which is marked by a yellow, '47.' At the start is a slight bulge. This connects to a very clean, left arching flake. This flake terminates at a roof. The original version of this route (as I was told) continued right of this roof, through easier climbing. However, a more fun (and 5.9) variation is to ascend the crack in the roof and continue up the face past two bolts to the fixed anchor. Excellent route!

Protection: G.

Start on bolts left of double lead, but then crosses over it.

bolts

Immediately to the left of Camel is a shallow, left facing flake (quite solid) whose crack gradually enlarges as it moves up the face. Ascend this flake system to a bulge (crack will continue up and right), which is to the left. Pull the bulge, which has no natural protection, but has a bolt. Atop the bulge a crack emerges and ascends up a shallow, right facing corner. This crack eats pro. Climb this to a resting stance. Gain the ledge to the wrap station. Note: someone denigrated this route by bolting it in its entirety. The route is truly a mixed route, with the only required bolt being the one at the bulge.

Mixed.  Please be an honorable climber: use pro.
This is large area that includes a wide range of sport and trad lines.  The hallmark of this area is a trad line called Camel, which is a classic 5.7.
